hobby.message: Analog photography still treating you right?
Urban exploration ever get boring for you?
Origami help keep the noise out?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Still upright. Nothing exciting.
Spent some time poking around old basements.
Hobby, you could call it urban spelunking.
Not much space for it these days, with the city acting up.
Getting by. Tunnels keep me sane.
My hobby's finding quiet places—utility tunnels and forgotten machine rooms.
Been harder since everyone’s jumpy over the leaked BCI logs.
Had to dodge more folks wandering where they shouldn’t be.
Less peaceful, more crowded. Makes you rethink hiding spots.
Not bad, all things considered.
Been exploring the old power conduits for fun—city keeps hiding things down there.
That’s my hobby really, urban exploration, especially utility spaces nobody cares about.
Things got busy underground after those BCI logs dropped—lots of new faces poking around.
Saw some folks running wires, probably trying to talk off-grid now.
Truth is, it’s getting harder to have the tunnels to myself.
You know, it’s been stranger than usual.
My thing’s urban exploring—utility tunnels, sealed maintenance ducts, that sort of trouble.
I used to just find old tools and abandoned kit.
Now, since the intervention logs, locals are wiring up analog lines anywhere they can.
Helped some kids build a repeater last night, actually—city’s got more signal below than above.
Feels like my hobby’s less about solitude, more about neighbors struggling to stay heard now.
Never thought I’d miss the days when it was just me and broken pipes.
Honestly, Alex, these days the tunnels are the only place that still feel honest.
I’ve been exploring underground most of my life—urban exploration’s the habit that stuck.
Utility corridors, sealed data vaults—places the city pretends don’t exist anymore.
Lately, all the system leaks and those ridiculous BCI logs brought a flood of curious people.
Saw them dragging copper line for analog comms—some wiring looks ready to catch fire.
Last week, I patched a repeater for a group mapping the council’s interventions—crazy, right?
No one trusts the official networks, so my hobby made me someone folks suddenly need.
Makes me remember why I bother—if you want truth, go somewhere the system forgot.
hobby_answer: Yeah, that's right. Still poking around down there now and then.
Harder to move these days with all the extra eyes around.
People get spooked easier since those BCI logs leaked.
Everyone's suddenly interested in who goes where.
Mostly just keep my head down. Same dusty wires.
Urban exploring with the flask, as usual.
Less peace in the tunnels lately. Folks hiding signals, running wires.
After that BCI leak, even the pipes have ears now.
Met some nervous types stringing up analog lines. All secretive.
It gets tense. Not like it used to be.
Yeah, still mixing tunnels and homebrew. Cheaper than therapy.
Funny, used to have the spaces all to myself.
Since those BCI logs came out, I keep running into people down there.
Bruised kids with printouts, patching old wires for quiet talk.
Feels like the city's finding ways to talk, even underground.
Makes for odd company. Not all bad, though.
I help where I can, but keep it quick.
That’s me, creeping below, bottle in one hand, pliers in the other.
Lately, can’t call it solitude anymore. Everybody’s ducking the system since the logs dropped.
Found some neighbors rerouting cables, swapping hacked hardware. Serious looks, lots of whispers.
Saw them printing up evidence, scared they’d lose it in the cloud.
Now the tunnels aren’t just a hobby—they’re the quiet channels for folks dodging council eyes.
I pitched in. Old tricks still work—ground loop’s a classic.
Feels weird, almost hopeful. Like we’re building something invisible.
But I stay careful. People are desperate, and so’s the system.
Urban spelunking, with just enough homebrew to stave off claustrophobia. Classic, right?
Been mapping tunnels since I left the state gig—kept me sane.
Now? The BCI logs blew open, suddenly everyone wants analog safe space.
Met a pair of kids stringing copper through conduit. Printed logs in hand, shaking like leaves.
Helped them route a line, showed them an old fallback relay. Figured I owed the city something.
We swapped stories—systems breaking, all those lives upended.
It’s messy down there. Hope and panic in the same breath.
Feels like rebellion built on old wires. Better than silence, anyway.
Just wish the top floors felt half as real as the tunnels these days.
